content.description: First bolt can easily be clipped by leaning in from the boulder alongside. Battle thru the cruxy thin face (or aid it), to insecure jams in vertical crack (10-).  Then follow angling crack up and right (9+/10-, good gear).
content.location: This is on the SE face of Bush Dome.  Approx 150 yards to the right of Ambush.  Downclimb off the dome to the right will bring you back to the base.

climbs.name: Lean on Me
climbs.fa: Jeff Rhoads, Kelly Rhoads and Todd Gordon, November 1989

content.description: This route features sustained, strenuous liebacking and jams.  It's in a shaded location.
content.location:
Crack to the right of

Chestwig

.

climbs.name: Kate's Bush
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Dave Evans, Marge Floyd, Jim Angione, Eric Charlton & Deanne Grey, September 1986

content.description: This route is on "Bush Dome" which is right and behind "Mel's Diner". Park at the turnout at "Roadside Rock", and walk a short distance west to the formations. "Kate's Bush" is on the right. You'll see a ledge about 25 feet above. Climb the crack system that takes you to the left side of the ledge. It is probably best to belay here. Then climb the obvious crack above. The lower crack is somewhat grainy and awkward(5.8), and the upper crack is a 5.7- joy.

climbs.name: Chestwig
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Marge Floyd, Jim Angione, Scott Gordon, Eric Charlton, and Todd Gordon, September 1986

content.description: This aesthetic and exciting climb follows a very thin crack with some face moves; shaded location.
content.location: an obvious thin crack on the left side of the crag

content.description:
A loose choss-filled chimney with a gritty friction finish.

Start inside of the chimney near a small protectable crack.  Move deeper into the chimney to get around a constriction (going outside may be possible).  The rock quality here is extremely bad and theres not good protection opportunities for a little bit.  After the constriction theres a small ledge where you can transition to an OK crack, or use wide chimney technique, to a large ledge.  The second, short pitch ascends some terrible quality gritty friction (oxymoron?).  Youll probably have to clean off every feature before planting a foot.  Oh, and there's only one placement opportunity, towards the start of the pitch.

Might be an ok route if it cleans up, a lot.
content.protection:
Your back and legs.

Small to 2.  A couple of 3s or 4s would be nice for the anchor at P1, but it can be reasonably protected with 1s and 2s.
content.location: About 50 feet right of ??, in the large inset.  Scramble up to a platform with a couple of smaller, decent looking crack climbs.  You wont be climbing those.  Instead, look to the left for a dirty, dingy, choss-filled chimney between the wall and a pillar.  Thats it.

content.description:
Pleasant adventurous J Tree climb!

Either go up on the right and go through a bush before traversing left, or undertake an awkward series of jams.  Establish in the obvious hand crack that seems steep for the grade.

Ascend some loose, grainy rock on rounded feet before a horizontal shelf without good pro. Follow the obvious hand crack up and go right as it does.  If you place just before the crack cuts right, make sure to extend long to avoid drag! Being able to hear and be heard by your belayer may be hard at the anchor.

Seems like a series of cruxes exist. Fairly sustained before the very final low angle section.  Likely harder than meets the eye.  But if you know J Tree, that's nothing new, right?
content.protection: Pro to 2".  Medium gear for the crack anchor.
content.location:
Pass the east face climbs on your left.  Beanie Babies can be found on the west corner nearly opposite the listed climbs. Scramble up a few boulders to begin.

Descend the south as per east face climbs.

climbs.name: Ambush
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Chris Baumann, Jared Stiles, & Todd Gordon, October 2018

content.description:
This is a tightly bolted sport climb on the northwest face.

S

equential face climbing up a near-vertical wall with a bunch of tricky moves make this a tough on-sight. An interesting combination of slopers, edges, sidepulls, balancey footwork and a few stout pulls in the mix.

Super-duper well protected at the hard moves.
content.location:
On the northwest face. Gets shade in the AM, sun in the PM.

The anchor can be also be accessed by climbing the crack just to the right (Beanie Babies 5.6; double rack from .75 to 3 inches.)
